caseTitle: THE REPUBLIC VRS THE HIGH COURT, ACCRA -PARTE
summary: The Supreme Court of Ghana, exercising its supervisory jurisdiction under Article 132 of the 1992 Constitution, granted an order of certiorari to quash a High Court ruling of 29 March 2011 that had committed Dr. Ernest Asiedu Osafu Alex Aboagye to prison for contempt of court. The contempt order was based on the applicant's failure to comply with a prior judgment of 26 January 2009, which the Supreme Court found to be fundamentally flawed. That earlier judgment, entered in default under Order 13 rule 6(2) of CI 47, included a declaratory order made without affording the defendant an opportunity to be heard, thereby violating the constitutional right to fair hearing under Article 14(1) and the principles of natural justice (audi alteram partem). The Supreme Court held that such a breach renders the proceedings a nullity, and since the contempt order depended on this defective judgment, it could not stand. The Court emphasized that violations of fundamental rights, especially the right to be heard, cannot be remedied under procedural rules like Order 81 of CI 47 and necessitate supervisory intervention.
verdict: The application for certiorari was granted; the High Court's ruling of 29 March 2011 committing the applicant to prison for contempt was quashed due to lack of jurisdiction arising from a prior violation of the right to fair hearing.
winningSide: The Republic (Applicant/Interested Party Dr. Ernest Asiedu Osafu Alex Aboagye)
citations: Order 13 rule 6(2), High Court (Civil Procedure) Rules, 2004 (CI 47)

rationaleHighlights: The High Court's 26 January 2009 declaratory judgment was made without affording the defendant an opportunity to be heard, violating audi alteram partem.
A breach of natural justice, particularly the right to a fair hearing, renders judicial proceedings a nullity.
Contempt order of 29 March 2011 was based on a fundamentally flawed prior judgment and thus lacked legal foundation.
The Supreme Court exercised its supervisory jurisdiction under Article 132 to quash the contempt ruling.
Procedural defects in granting default declaratory relief cannot be cured under Order 81 of CI 47 when fundamental rights are violated.
